solution_line_template: Two kilograms of sugar is priced at ${sugar_cost_per_kg} x {sugar_kg_L1} = $<<{sugar_kg_L1}*{sugar_cost_per_kg}={cost_two_kg_sugar}>>{cost_two_kg_sugar}.
Three kilograms of sugar is priced at ${sugar_cost_per_kg} x {sugar_kg_L2} = $<<{sugar_kg_L2}*{sugar_cost_per_kg}={cost_three_kg_sugar}>>{cost_three_kg_sugar}.
So five kilograms of salt is priced at ${total_cost_sugar_salt} - ${cost_two_kg_sugar} = ${cost_five_kg_salt}.
Thus, a kilogram of salt is priced at ${cost_five_kg_salt}/{salt_kg_L4} = $<<{cost_five_kg_salt}/{salt_kg_L4}={cost_one_kg_salt}>>{cost_one_kg_salt}.
Hence, three kilograms of sugar and a kilogram of salt.s price is ${cost_three_kg_sugar} + ${cost_one_kg_salt} = ${final_price}.
